title: 107_s1093
content:
The Act titled "Veterans' Benefits Programs Modification Act of 2001" excludes certain additional income from annual income determinations for pension purposes. The "Veterans' Benefits Programs Modification Act of 2001" amends section 1503 of title 38, United States Code to exclude life insurance proceeds and other non-recurring income from annual income determinations for pension purposes. The amendments take effect on January 1, 2002. SEC. 3. The effective dates of awards and reductions of benefits are being amended. The 45-Day Rule for the effective date of death pension awards is repealed, and the effective date of changes in recurring income for benefits purposes is clarified. SEC. 4. There is a time limitation on providing claim information to the Department of Veterans Affairs. Section 5102 of title 38, United States Code, is amended to include a new subsection regarding a time limitation for submitting necessary information for benefits applications. If the required information is not received within one year of notification, no benefits will be provided. This amendment does not apply to Government life insurance benefits. Additionally, Section 5103 is amended to repeal outdated provisions. These amendments are effective as of November 9, 2000. The amendment is effective as if enacted on November 9, 2000, immediately after the Veterans Claims Assistance Act of 2000. SEC. 5. CLARIFICATION OF EFFECTIVE DATE OF MODIFICATIONS OF DUTY TO ASSIST. Section 7 of the Veterans Claims Assistance Act of 2000 is amended to clarify amendments to chapter 51 of title 38, United States Code. This includes specifying when a decision had not been issued by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs before a certain date. The Veterans Claims Assistance Act of 2000 was amended to clarify decisions made by the Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims in the Morton case. The amendments specify when a decision became final and was issued by the Secretary or a court due to a claim not being well grounded. The amendments made by subsection (a) will be effective as if included in the enactment of the Veterans Claims Assistance Act of 2000. Prohibition on providing certain benefits to veterans who are fugitive felons. Prohibition on providing benefits to veterans who are fugitive felons: A veteran or dependent eligible for certain benefits may not receive them if the veteran is a fugitive felon fleeing prosecution or violating probation/parole. The law prohibits veterans or dependents from receiving certain benefits if the veteran is a fugitive felon or violates probation/parole. Benefits covered include those under specific chapters of the law, and the Secretary must provide the current address of eligible veterans to law enforcement upon request. The law requires officials to provide information to the Secretary to identify veterans who are fugitives and certify that apprehending them is within their duties. The Secretary can share this information with law enforcement agencies. The law prohibits certain benefits for veterans who are fugitive felons. Congress believes that agreements should be made promptly after the enactment of the Act. Additionally, there is a limitation on compensation for veterans incarcerated for felonies committed before October 7, 1980. Veterans entitled to compensation who were incarcerated for a felony before October 7, 1980, and remain in prison after the enactment of this Act, will have their compensation subject to certain provisions of title 38, United States Code. This section will take effect 90 days after the Act's enactment and will apply to compensation payments starting from that date. The term "compensation" for veterans incarcerated for a felony before October 7, 1980, will be defined as per section 5313 of title 38, United States Code. Eligibility for survivors' and dependents' educational assistance for spouses and surviving spouses of veterans with total service-connected disabilities is addressed in Section 8. Designation of Eligibility under title 38, United States Code, is amended to include new subsections regarding entitlement deductions for eligible persons. Section 3512 is also amended to remove subsection (g). The amendment to title 38, United States Code, includes provisions for educational assistance eligibility for certain individuals for a 10-year period. Surviving spouses may have a longer period if previously eligible. Eligible persons can elect a later start date for the 10-year period with approval from the Secretary. The amendment allows eligible individuals to choose a later start date for a 10-year period of educational assistance, with approval from the Secretary. This applies to determinations of eligibility for spouses or surviving spouses under chapter 35 of title 38, United States Code. The amendment allows surviving spouses to apply for educational assistance under chapter 35 of title 38, United States Code, after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 9. Repeals fiscal year limitation on number of veterans in programs of independent living services and assistance. First priority in provision of such programs. Effective date is September 30, 2001.

SEC. 10. Increases home loan guaranty amount for construction and purchase of homes to $63,175.
